name: 댐 유지관리
contents: 1. 일반사항1.1 목적(1) 이 기준은 댐 시설물 유지관리에 필요한 체계적인 기준을 제시하는 것을 목적으로 한다.1.2 적용범위(1) 이 기준은 댐과 부대시설 또는 공작물의 운영 및 유지관리를 위한 제반 사항을 규정한 것으로 댐건설관리법에 의하여 설치되어 운영중인 댐 시설의 유지관리에 적용한다. (2) 이 기준은 농업용댐을 제외한 다른 법령에 의하여 설치되어 운영중인 댐 및 소규모댐 시설의 유지관리에 발주자의 승인을 얻어 적용할 수 있다. 1.3 참고 기준1.3.1  관련 법규. 기반시설관리법. 댐건설･관리 및 주변지역지원 등에 관한 법률(댐건설관리법). 물환경보전법. 수자원의 조사․계획 및 관리에 관한 법률(수자원법). 시설물의 안전 및 유지관리에 관한 특별법(시설물안전법). 저수지․댐의 안전관리 및 재해예방에 관한 법률(저수지.댐법). 지속가능한 기반시설 관리 기본법(기반시설관리법). 하천법1.3.2  관련 기준   내용 없음1.4 용어의 정의. 댐관리주체: 관계 법에 따라 댐시설의 관리책임을 지는 기관. 댐관리: 관련 법에 따른 댐과 그 저수 및 저수구역 내 토지, 수면, 수질 등을 관리를 하는 것. 댐관리자: 관련 법에 따라 댐의 관리를 위탁받은 자. 댐사용권자: 댐에 의한 일정량의 저수를 일정한 지역에 확보하고 특정용도에 사용할 수 있는 권리를 가진 자. 댐설치자: 관련 법에 따라 댐을 설치한 자. 댐안전관리 업무종사자: 댐 시설물의 안전점검, 유지보수 및 재난관리업무를 담당하는 자. 드론: 고위험 및 접근성 결여지역의 안전점검을 위해, 비대면 및 무인조작이 가능한 초경량무인항공장치 . 수중 ROV(Remotely Operated Vehicle): 사람의 접근성이 열악한 수중에서 무인조사가 가능한 원격조정 수중로봇. 부유물: 댐, 저수지, 하천 등에 유입되어 수질오염 및 환경악화를 야기하는 초목류, 생활쓰레기 등 고체성 물질. 상시만수위: 이수목적으로 활용되는 부분의 최고수위. 생애주기비용: 시설물의 계획, 설계, 건설, 운영, 유지관리, 성능개선, 해체, 처분 등에 이르는 생애주기 전체에 걸쳐 발생하는 총비용. 유지관리: 완공된 시설물의 기능을 보전하고자, 시설물을 일상적으로 점검ㆍ정비하고 손상된 부분을 원상복구하며 경과시간에 따라 요구되는 시설물의 보수.보강 등에 필요한 활동을 하는 것. 저수구역: 계획홍수위선으로 둘러싸인 지역으로서 하천법에 의한 하천구역으로 지정.고시된 지역. 홍수기: 홍수가 발생할 우려가 큰 기간으로 그 기간은 관련 정부 부처에서 결정1.5 기호의 정의내용 없음1.6 댐시설의 유지관리 일반(1) 댐관리주체는 시설물의 생애주기를 감안하여 안전하고 지속가능한 댐 시설물의 확보를 위한 운영관리방안을 고려하여야 한다.(2) 댐시설의 안전성, 사용성, 내구성 등을 종합적으로 고려하여 선제적으로 관리함으로써 노후화에 따른 생애주기비용 최소화를 위한 다음과 같은 사항을 시행하여야 한다.  ① 댐에 대한 효과적이고 체계적이며 지속적인 점검과 사전 정비② 댐체 및 부속 수리구조물에 대한 철저한 관리 및 정비③ 개․보수의 타당성을 사전에 충분히 검토하여 적정규모와 기준의 적합성 여부 등에 대한 운영방침 수립④ 성능평가와 그에 따른 성능개선⑤ 철저한 작업계획을 통한 불필요한 예산 낭비의 감소⑥ 유지관리 인력의 정예화(3) 장수명화를 위하여 스마트 유지관리 신기술, 자산관리시스템 도입 등 4차산업혁명 시대에 부합하는 댐 시설물의 유지관리 방안을 고려하여야 한다.2. 조사 및 계획   내용 없음3. 재료   내용 없음4. 설계   내용 없음5. 유지관리5.1 자료관리5.1.1 자료관리 일반(1) 수자원법 제25조에 따른 수자원정보체계를 구축하고 운영하여야 한다.(2) 댐을 유지관리하는데 필요한 댐의 계획, 조사, 설계와 시공은 물론 운영중의 보수이력사항 등의 각종 기초자료를 체계적으로 정리하여 보관하고 관리하여야 한다.(3) 자료는 그 중요성에 따라 보존 기간을 달리할 수 있으므로 목록표에는 자료의 보존기간을 명시하여 관리하여야 한다.5.1.2 수위 및 강우량의 관측⋅기록(1) 댐관리자는 댐의 수위와 유역내의 강우량을 실시간으로 관측하고, 관측결과를 데이터베이스에 저장.보관하여야 한다.(2) 수위관측은 해당 댐에 설치된 수위계를 사용하여야 하며, 수위계는 방류 및 취수 등 급격한 수위의 변화가 없는 안정된 저수면에 설치되어야 한다.5.1.3 수문자료의 관측⋅관리(1) 댐관리자는 댐의 관리에 필요한 다음 각 호의 사항을 관측하고 관측결과 및 수집자료를 기록.보관하여야 한다.① 기상청 등의 관측결과를 이용할 수 있는 사항을 제외한 기상에 관한 사항 ② 수위, 유입량, 방류량, 수온, 퇴사량, 수질 및 취수량 등 수문에 관한 사항③ 용수공급량, 발전방류량 등 방류량, 발전량 등 댐 운영에 관한 사항④ 그 밖에 댐의 운영에 필요한 사항(2) 관측방법.주기 등 관측에 필요한 사항은 수자원법 제10조의 관련 규정에서 정한 기준을 따르되 규정되지 않은 사항은 댐관리자가 따로 정하여야 한다(3) 댐관리자는 수자원법 시행령 제10조의 수문관측자료의 품질관리를 위한 기술기준을 수립하여야 하며, 기준에 따라 수문관측자료를 실시간, 연간 단위로 품질관리 하여야 한다.  5.1.4 자료의 보관⋅관리(1) 댐관리자는 댐 및 부속시설물의 관리에 필요한 다음의 자료를 보관.관리하여야 한다.① 타당성조사, 기본계획, 예비설계, 지질조사, 실시설계, 건설, 준공, 용지보상 등 댐건설에 관한 각종 보고서, 도면, 설계서, 수리.수문.구조계산서, 공사지 등 댐건설 관련 자료② 댐 및 부속시설물에 관한 점검.정비.보수 등 이력사항③ 계측설비 측정자료④ 홍수 분석자료⑤ 방류량 결정을 위한 댐하류 수리권에 관한 자료⑥ 저수지내 수질측정에 관한 자료⑦ 그 밖에 댐 및 저수지 관리에 관한 자료(2) 댐관리자는 수문관측자료를 유관기관과 상호교환하고 공동 활용하여야 한다.5.1.5 관리연보의 작성(1) 댐관리자는 매년 홍수기 이전까지 댐관리에 관한 사항을 기재한 댐관리연보를 작성.비치하여야 한다. 이 경우, 수자원법 시행령 제23조에 따른 수문조사에 관한 자료를 제공하여야 한다.5.2 유지관리 체제5.2.1 댐관리 및 조직(1) 댐관리자는 물관리 기관에 의해 결정된 물 이용의 기본방침, 비용부담의 조정, 갈수 조정, 물 이용 등을 존중하여 댐을 관리하고 운용하여야 한다.  ① 댐관리자는 댐 관리에 있어서  하천법 시행규칙에 정해진 규정, 기타 관계법령을 준수하여야 한다. ② 댐관리자는 댐관리시 용수공급과 시설조작 및 유지관리 등에 있어서 댐사용권자의 의지를 반영하여야 한다.③ 댐사용권자 내부 또는 복수의 댐사용권자간의 조정 및 의사 결정을 하기 위한 관리조직을 만들어 기능 및 권한을 명확히 하여야 한다.(2) 댐관리 기술의 향상 및 댐의 기능, 규모에 맞는 관리요원을 확보하여 관리체제의 정비를 도모하며 안전하게 댐관리를 수행하여야 한다.① 댐 관리기술의 향상을 위해 4차산업혁명 시대에 부합하는 기계화, 자동화, 지능화 등 관리시스템의 합리화 및 고도화를 추진하여야 한다.  ② 댐 운영은 홍수, 지진 등 예측하기 어려운 자연현상을 대상으로 하고 있어 사람의 판단에 의존하는 경우가 많기 때문에 댐 규모에 합당한 수의 관리요원을 확보하고 관리체제의 정비를 도모하여 적정의 댐관리를 실시하여야 한다.③ 관리조직체제는 평상시는 물론 홍수, 지진 등에도 대처가 가능하도록 긴급시 관리체제, 명령계통, 통보연락처, 작업내용 등을 조직기구도로 명확하게 구성하여 관계자에게 주지시켜야 한다.5.2.2 댐 관리업무 종사자의 교육 등(1) 댐설치자는 댐의 적정한 관리를 위하여 하천법 시행규칙 제21조에서 정하는 자격을 가진 관리 기술자를 댐 및 관리시설의 규모와 관리업무 등에 따라 필요 인원을 확보하고 배치하여야 한다.  (2) 댐관리자는 댐운영업무 종사자에 대해 이.치수 관련 자체 교육계획을 수립하여 시행하여야 한다.(3) 댐관리자는 댐 안전관리업무 종사자가 저수지.댐법 제25조에 따라 교육을 받도록 하여야 한다. (4) 댐관리자는 수문조사 업무종사자가 수자원법 및 같은 법 시행령 제11조에 따른 교육을 이수토록 하여야 한다.5.3 댐 시설물의 유지관리5.3.1 댐 시설물 유지관리 일반(1) 댐관리주체는 기반시설관리법 제11조에 따른 최소유지관리기준 이상으로 유지관리하여야 한다.(2) 댐관리주체는 기반시설관리법 제16조에 따른 기반시설 관리시스템을 이용하여 유지관리 현황 등의 자료 및 정보를 통보하거나 제출하여야 한다. (3) 점검은 댐 본체와 기초지반 및 주변 산지, 취.방류설비 등에 대하여 상태변화 유무를 확인하고, 변화가 있는 경우 변화의 정도와 추이에 대한 감시를 실시하여야 한다.(4) 계측 또는 점검의 결과, 보다 상세한 조사를 필요로 하는 경우는 정밀조사를 실시하여야 하며, 정밀조사는 설계자료, 공사기록, 계측, 점검기록, 기타 필요한 자료를 조사한 후 적절한 방법을 정하여 실시하여야 한다.(5) 정밀조사 결과, 보수가 필요하다고 인정되는 경우는 신속히 이를 실시하여 댐의 안전을 확보하여야 하고 그 기능을 유지하도록 하여야 한다. (6) 정밀조사의 필요가 없는 경우에도 점검에 의해 발견된 손상은 그 정도에 따라 필요한 보수를 실시하여, 댐을 항상 양호한 상태로 유지하도록 하여야 한다.(7) 계측과 점검 혹은 정밀조사 결과, 댐의 안전관리상 필요하다고 인정되는 경우는 응급조치를 실시하여, 댐의 안전을 확보하여야 한다.(8) 댐은 완공 후에도 계측 등에 의해서 거동을 수시로 파악하여야 하며, 비상시에 대비한 신속한 응급대책을 위한 비상대처계획을 수립하여 댐 붕괴로 인한 재해를 방지할 수 있어야 한다.(9) 댐 시설물의 유지관리의 목적은 초기에 변형이나 결함을 정확히 파악하여 가장 적절한 대책을 수립하는 것이므로 결함의 예측, 점검, 평가 및 판정 대책, 기록 등을 합리적으로 조합시켜 순서에 따라 대처하여야 한다.5.3.2 안전점검 및 유지보수(1) 안전 및 유지관리계획① 댐관리자는 댐의 정상적인 기능유지를 위하여 매년 소관 시설물별로 안전 및 유지관리계획을 수립하여야 한다. ② 시설물안전법 대상 댐의 경우, 안전 및 유지관리계획은 같은 법 제55조에 따른 시설물 정보관리 종합시스템을 통하여 제출하여야 한다.. ③ 안전 및 유지관리계획에는 다음 사항이 포함되어야 한다.가. 시설물의 적정한 안전과 유지관리를 위한 조직.인원 및 장비의 확보에 관한 사항나. 긴급상황 발생 시 조치체계에 관한 사항다. 시설물의 설계.시공.감리 및 유지관리 등과 관련된 설계도서의 수집과 보존에 관한 사항라. 안전점검 또는 정밀안전진단 실시계획 및 보수.보강 계획에 관한 사항마. 안전과 유지관리에 필요한 비용에 관한 사항바. 전년도 안전점검, 정밀안전진단 및 변경이 필요한 경우 보완하여야 한다.가. 댐의 개요 및 주변환경나. 비상연락체계다. 비상경보의 발령절차 등에 관한 사항라. 비상시 응급행동 요령마. 그 밖에 비상대처에 필요한 사항③ 댐관리자는 댐안전과 관련된 기준이나 구조의 변경 또는 댐하류 하천의 현저한 변화가 있는 경우와 댐관리주체의 지시가 있는 경우에는 댐관리주체를 대행하여 비상대처계획을 재수립할 수 있다.(3) 댐 사고의 대처① 댐관리자는 댐의 안전과 기능을 유지하는 데 중대한 장애가 되는 시설물의 결함이나 사고 등이 발견되거나 발생할 때에는 지체없이 응급 안전조치를 하여야 한다.② 댐관리자는 댐의 중대한 결함.붕괴 등의 사고가 발생한 때에는 관계부처, 전문가 등으로 조사반을 구성.조사하여야 한다.③ 댐관리자는 발생현황, 응급조치 및 사고원인 조사 결과는 지체없이 관계기관에 보고하여야 한다.④ 댐관리자는 위험 가능 조건을 적절히 판단할 수 있도록 댐 자체와 댐 지점의 특성을 숙지하고 있는 댐안전관리 업무종사자를 1인 이상 배치하여야 한다.⑤ 댐안전관리 종사자는 댐 파괴나 사고를 유발할 수 있는 다음과 같은 이상 거동이나 징후를 발견하였을 경우, 이를 방지하고 경감시키기 위한 위기대응 행동요령에 따라 대처하여야 한다.가. 홍수류에 의한 월류나. 폭풍이나 태풍에 의한 댐체 침식다. 댐체 상.하류의 비탈면 활동(sliding)라. 침투수 및 누수의 발생마. 부속 구조물의 붕괴5.3.9 댐홍수예경보시스템 설치 및 운영(1) 댐관리자는 댐 등의 효율적인 운영을 위하여 댐 상.하류의 강수량, 수위 등을 관측하는 수문관측설비와 댐 저수를 방류할 때 음성방송, 사이렌 또는 확성기 등을 통해 하류주민에게 주의사항을 알리기 위한 경보방송설비를 총칭하는 댐홍수예경보시스템을 설치.운영하여야 한다.(2) 수문관측설비는 관측기기(수위계 및 우량계 등), 관측자료 저장.전송장치, 통신장치와 전원장치로 구성하며 경보방송설비는 스피커, 경보장치, 통신장치와 전원장치로 구성하여야 한다.(3) 댐홍수예경보시스템은 중요성 및 현장 여건에 따라 선택적으로 이중화로 구성할 수 있다.(4) 댐관리자는 효율적인 수자원관리 및 재해예방을 위해 댐홍수예경보시스템에 대한 운영관리 기준을 수립하여야 한다.(5) 댐관리자는 댐홍수예경보시스템이 상시 동작 가능토록 정기 및 수시 점검정비를 실시하여야 한다 5.4 저수지 수질 및 환경관리5.4.1 수질 및 생태환경관리(1) 저수지 수환경① 댐관리자는 저수지 내의 급격한 수질변화, 이상 생물 증식 등의 특이현상 발생 시 관계기관과 협조하여 그 원인을 분석하고 수질 및 수생태에 미치는 영향을 파악하는 등 관련 법령에 의한 피해 예방조치를 취하여야 한다.② 댐관리자는 저수지에 조류 수가 크게 증가하거나 증가가 예상되는 경우 관계기관과 협조하여 원인을 분석하고 발생 억제 및 피해를 최소화 하여야 한다.(2) 탁수 및 부유물 관리① 댐관리자는 홍수기 전 저수지 상류지역에 대한 조사를 통해 탁수 및 부유물 발생원을 확인한 후, 관계기관에 적절한 조치를 요청하는 등 탁수와 부유물의 저수지내 유입이 최소화 되도록 하여야 한다.② 댐관리자는 저수지 내로 유입된 탁수에 대하여 댐운영 및 하류하천 탁도의 정도를 감안하여 선택적 배제를 실시할 수 있다.③ 댐관리자는 저수지에 부유물 등이 유입된 경우 신속히 수거하여 저수구역이 깨끗하게 유지될 수 있도록 하여야 하며, 수거한 부유물의 운반 및 처리를 위하여 물환경보전법 제31조에 따라 해당 지방자치단체와 사전에 협의하거나 협약을 체결하여야 한다. (3) 댐관리자는 댐유역 내 점/비점 오염원 및 이들 오염원으로 부터의 오염물질 배출 현황을 관련 보고서 검토, 현장 조사 등을 수행하여 사전에 파악하여야 한다.(4) 댐관리자는 수질보전 및 개선을 위하여 저수구역 내에 수질보전시설(수중폭기시설, 조류방지막, 인공습지 등)을 설치.운영할 수 있다. 5.4.2 오염원 관리 및 위기대응(1) 오염행위 감시① 댐관리자는 저수지의 수질을 오염시킬 수 있는 행위를 발견한 때에는 지체 없이 관계기관에 고발 등 필요한 조치를 하여야 한다.(2) 오염사고 대처① 관리자는 저수구역 및 댐 저수에 직접적으로 영향을 미치는 지역에 기름유출, 어류 집단폐사 등 돌발적인 수질오염사고에 대비하여 사고 유형별 대응체계를 구축하여야 하며, 모의훈련을 통해 수질오염사고 발생 시 신속하고 체계적인 방제조치가 가능하도록 모의훈련을 실시하여야 한다.② 관리자는 저수지 수질보전 및 수질오염사고 발생시 신속한 대응 등을 위해 상시적인 비상연락망을 구축하여야 하며, 관계기관과의 원활한 소통이 가능토록 긴밀한 협조체제를 유지하여야 한다.

1. General Provisions 1.1 Purpose (1) This standard aims to provide systematic criteria required for the maintenance of dam facilities. 1.2 Scope of Application (1) This standard specifies all matters related to the operation and maintenance of dams, associated facilities, and structures, and applies to the maintenance of dam facilities operated under the Dam Construction Management Act. (2) This standard may be applied to the maintenance of dams and small dams installed and operated under other laws, excluding agricultural dams, with the approval of the client. 1.3 Reference Standard 1. 3.1 Related Laws and Regulations. Public Utility Management Act. Act on the Construction, Management, and Support of Local Areas around Dams (Dam Construction and Management Act). Water Environment Conservation Act. Act on the Survey, Planning, and Management of Water Resources (Water Resources Act). Special Act on Safety Management and Maintenance of Structures (Facility Safety Act). Act on Safety Management of Reservoirs and Dams and Disaster Prevention (Reservoir and Dam Act). Sustainable Public Infrastructure Management Basic Act (Public Utility Management Act). River Act. 1. 3.2 Related Standards - None 1.4 Definitions.

Dam Management Entity: An entity responsible for the management of dam facilities according to related laws and regulations.

Dam Management: The management of the dam itself, as well as the land, water surface, and water quality within the reservoir and downstream area, in accordance with relevant laws and regulations.

Dam Manager: A person entrusted with the management of the dam according to related laws and regulations.

Dam Water Right Holder: A person who has the right to secure a certain amount of water storage through the dam in a specific area and use it for a specific purpose.

Dam Constructor: A person who constructs the dam according to related laws and regulations.

Dam Safety Management Personnel: Personnel responsible for the safety inspection, maintenance, and disaster management of dam facilities.

Drone: A lightweight unmanned aerial vehicle capable of non-contact and remote operation, used for safety inspections in high-risk and inaccessible areas.

Underwater ROV (Remotely Operated Vehicle): A remotely operated underwater robot capable of unmanned investigation in underwater environments with limited accessibility.

Floating Debris: Solid materials, such as aquatic vegetation and household waste, that flow into dams, reservoirs, and rivers, causing water pollution and environmental degradation.

Normal High Water Level: The maximum water level utilized for irrigation purposes.

Life Cycle Cost: The total cost incurred throughout the entire life cycle of a facility, including planning, design, construction, operation, maintenance, performance improvement, decommissioning, and disposal.

Maintenance: Activities undertaken to preserve the functionality of completed facilities, including regular inspection and maintenance, restoration of damaged parts, and necessary repairs and reinforcements based on the passage of time.

Reservoir Area: An area surrounded by the planned flood level line, designated and announced as a river area according to the River Act.

Flood Season: A period when there is a high risk of flooding, the duration of which is determined by the relevant government agency. Definition of 1.5 symbol not available. 1.6 General Maintenance of Dam Facilities (1) The dam management entity shall consider operation and management plans to secure safe and sustainable dam facilities, taking into account the life cycle of the facilities. (2) To minimize life-cycle costs due to aging, the dam facilities shall be proactively managed by comprehensively considering safety, usability, and durability, and the following measures shall be implemented: ① Effective, systematic, and continuous inspection and pre-maintenance of the dam ② Thorough management and maintenance of the dam body and related hydraulic structures ③ Prior sufficient review of the feasibility of renovation and repair, establishing operational policies regarding the appropriateness of the scale and standards ④ Performance evaluation and subsequent performance improvement ⑤ Reduction of unnecessary budget waste through thorough work planning ⑥ Strengthening of maintenance personnel (3) To ensure longevity, consideration shall be given to dam facility maintenance plans that are in line with the era of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, such as the introduction of smart maintenance technologies and asset management systems. 2. Survey and Planning - None 3. Materials - None 4. Design - None 5. Maintenance Data Management 5.1 5. 1.1 General Data Management (1) A water information system as stipulated in Article 25 of the Water Resources Act shall be established and operated. (2) Basic data, including plans, surveys, designs, construction, and maintenance records related to the maintenance of dams, shall be systematically organized, stored, and managed. (3) Since the retention period of data may vary depending on its importance, the retention period of each document shall be specified in the list and managed accordingly. 5. 1.2 Observation and Recording of Water Level and Precipitation (1) The dam manager shall observe the water level of the dam and the precipitation within the watershed in real time, and store and keep the observation results in a database. (2) Water level measurement shall be performed using a water level gauge installed in the dam, and the gauge shall be installed in a stable reservoir area where rapid water level changes due to discharge and intake do not occur. 5. 1.3 Observation and Management of Hydrological Data (1) The dam manager shall observe the following items necessary for the management of the dam and record and store the observation results and collected data. ① Matters concerning weather, excluding those that can utilize the observation results of the Korea Meteorological Administration, etc. ② Matters concerning the water body, such as water level, inflow, outflow, water temperature, sediment load, water quality, and water intake. ③ Matters concerning dam operation, such as water supply, outflow for power generation, outflow, power generation, etc. ④ Other matters necessary for the operation of the dam. (2) Observation methods, frequency, and other necessary items for observation shall follow the standards specified in Article 10 of the Water Resources Act, and if not specified, shall be separately determined by the dam manager. (3) The dam manager shall establish technical standards for quality management of hydrological observation data as stipulated in Article 10 of the Enforcement Decree of the Water Resources Act, and shall quality manage the hydrological observation data in real-time and annual units according to the standards. 5. 1.4 Data Storage and Management (1) The dam manager shall store and manage the following data necessary for the management of the dam and its appurtenances. ① Various reports, drawings, design documents, hydraulic, hydrological, and structural calculation sheets, and construction records related to dam construction, including feasibility studies, basic plans, preliminary designs, geological surveys, detailed designs, construction, completion, and land compensation, etc. ② Records of inspections, maintenance, and repairs of the dam and its appurtenances. ③ Measurement data from monitoring equipment. ④ Flood analysis data. ⑤ Data related to water rights downstream of the dam for determining discharge volumes. ⑥ Data related to water quality measurements in the reservoir. ⑦ Other data related to the management of the dam and reservoir. (2) The dam manager shall exchange and jointly utilize hydrological data with related organizations. 5. 1.5 Preparation of Annual Management Report (1) The dam manager shall prepare and keep a dam management report containing details of dam management affairs before the flood season each year. In this case, data related to hydrological surveys as stipulated in Article 23 of the Enforcement Decree of the Water Resources Management Act shall be provided. 5.2 Maintenance System 5. 2.1 Dam Management and Organization (1) The dam manager shall manage and operate the dam with due respect for the basic policies for water use, adjustment of cost burdens, drought adjustment, and water use determined by the water management agency. ① The dam manager shall comply with the provisions stipulated in the Enforcement Regulations of the River Act and other relevant laws and regulations in dam management. ② The dam manager shall reflect the intentions of the water right holders in dam management, particularly in water supply, facility operation, and maintenance. ③ A management organization shall be established to facilitate coordination and decision-making among water right holders, either internally or between multiple water right holders, and its functions and authority shall be clearly defined. (2) Efforts shall be made to improve dam management technology, secure management personnel appropriate to the dam’s function and scale, and enhance the management system to ensure safe dam management. ① To improve dam management technology, rationalization and advancement of management systems, including mechanization, automation, and intelligence, in line with the era of the Fourth Industrial Revolution shall be promoted. ② Due to the nature of dam operation, which deals with unpredictable natural phenomena such as floods and earthquakes, and often relies on human judgment, an adequate number of management personnel should be secured based on the dam's scale, and the management system should be improved to implement appropriate dam management. ③ The management organizational structure shall be clearly configured in an organizational chart, specifying emergency management systems, command lines, contact information, and work content, to ensure readiness for contingencies such as floods and earthquakes, both during normal times and emergencies, and to inform relevant personnel. 5. 2.2 Education and Training of Dam Management Personnel (1) The dam operator shall secure and deploy the necessary number of qualified management technicians with qualifications as stipulated in Article 21 of the Enforcement Rules of the Rivers Act, in accordance with the scale of the dam and management facilities and the management tasks. (2) The dam manager shall establish and implement a self-developed training plan related to flood and drought management for personnel engaged in dam operation. (3) The dam manager shall ensure that personnel engaged in dam safety management receive training in accordance with Article 25 of the Reservoirs and Dams Act. (4) The dam manager shall ensure that personnel engaged in hydrological survey work complete training as stipulated in Article 11 of the Water Resources Act and its Enforcement Decree. 5.3 Dam Facility Maintenance 5. 3.1 General Maintenance of Dam Facilities
(1) The dam management entity shall maintain the dam in accordance with the minimum maintenance standards stipulated in Article 11 of the Public Facility Management Act or above.
(2) The dam management entity shall notify or submit data and information on the maintenance status, etc., using the public facility management system as stipulated in Article 16 of the Public Facility Management Act.
(3) Inspections shall be conducted on the dam body, foundation ground, surrounding mountains, intake/outlet facilities, etc., to confirm the presence or absence of changes in condition, and if changes are found, monitoring shall be conducted on the degree and trend of the changes.
(4) If more detailed investigation is required as a result of measurements or inspections, a detailed investigation shall be conducted. The detailed investigation shall be conducted after investigating design data, construction records, measurements, inspection records, and other necessary data, and determining an appropriate method.
(5) If the results of the detailed investigation warrant repairs, such repairs shall be carried out promptly to ensure the safety of the dam and maintain its function.
(6) Even if detailed investigation is not necessary, repairs shall be carried out as needed, in proportion to the extent of any damage found during inspections, to maintain the dam in a consistently sound condition.
(7) If deemed necessary for safety management of the dam as a result of measurements, inspections, or detailed investigations, emergency measures shall be taken to ensure the safety of the dam.
(8) The dam shall be monitored for its behavior through measurements, etc., even after completion, and an emergency response plan for rapid emergency measures in the event of an emergency shall be established to prevent disasters caused by dam collapse.
(9) The purpose of maintaining dam facilities is to accurately identify initial deformations or defects and establish the most appropriate measures. Therefore, defect prediction, inspection, evaluation, assessment measures, and records should be rationally combined and addressed in sequence. 5. 3.2 Safety Inspection and Maintenance (1) Safety and Maintenance Management Plan ① The dam manager shall establish an annual safety and maintenance management plan for each facility under their jurisdiction to ensure the normal function of the dam. ② In the case of dams subject to the Facility Safety Act, the safety and maintenance management plan shall be submitted through the Facility Information Management Comprehensive System as stipulated in Article 55 of the same Act. ③ The safety and maintenance management plan shall include the following items: a. Matters concerning the securing of organization, personnel, and equipment for the proper safety and maintenance of the facility; b. Matters concerning the response system in the event of an emergency; c. Matters concerning the collection and preservation of design documents related to the design, construction, supervision, and maintenance of the facility; d. Plans for safety inspections or detailed safety diagnoses and repair/reinforcement plans; e. Matters concerning the costs necessary for safety and maintenance; f. Records of safety inspections, detailed safety diagnoses, and repair/reinforcement activities in the previous year. ④ The safety and maintenance management plan for each facility shall establish inspection focus items to ensure systematic operation, operation, and maintenance of the facility. As needed, consider routine and detailed inspections using smart technologies based on the fourth industrial revolution, such as drones and underwater ROVs. (2) Implementation of Safety Inspections, etc. ① The dam manager shall conduct safety inspections and diagnoses of the following facilities to ensure the normal function of the dam. However, facilities and equipment requiring specialized expertise and requiring the maintenance of a high degree of precision, as prohibited by the manufacturer's specifications for various equipment and instruments, shall be inspected according to a separate inspection plan. a. Dam b. Gates, spillway gates, outlet works, emergency spillway, stilling basins, intake facilities, and outlet facilities c. Communication facilities and dam water level monitoring, flood warning, etc. d. Various equipment and facilities for gate operation, backup power facilities e. Other ancillary facilities ② The types of inspections shall be classified as safety inspections and detailed safety diagnoses conducted in accordance with Articles 11 to 13 of the Facility Safety Act, and various inspections conducted by the management entity. ③ The implementation of inspections and diagnoses shall be carried out in accordance with the relevant laws based on the type of inspection and diagnosis and the grade of the dam according to the relevant laws. Ad hoc inspections shall be conducted in the following cases: a. Before and after releasing water through the gate b. After the occurrence of heavy rainfall, typhoons, earthquakes, and other abnormal conditions c. When deemed necessary for facility maintenance management. ④ When conducting safety inspections, the dam manager shall recognize the vulnerable conditions of the dam structure and surrounding areas, or in the following cases, shall promote efficient maintenance management through safety reviews or risk assessments: a. Activity of the reservoir slope due to a rapid drop in reservoir water level b. Activity of the slope due to an earthquake c. Collapse of the slope due to construction or other man-made activities d. Activity of other concrete dams and other risk factors of the dam. ⑤ The dam manager shall conduct inspections of the facilities within the necessary scope in the event of any of the following, and take necessary measures such as repair and maintenance based on the results. a. Occurrence of an earthquake, heavy rain, or typhoon b. After releasing water through the gate c. When abnormal signs of the facility occur. (3) Maintenance ① The dam manager shall properly maintain the facilities in accordance with the safety and maintenance management plan. ② When the dam manager intends to carry out major reinforcement work such as improvement or replacement of the dam and its ancillary facilities, they shall obtain approval after consultation with the dam user. However, this shall not apply to routine maintenance work. ③ After comprehensively analyzing the results of the inspection, the dam manager shall refer to the dam facility maintenance lifespan criteria to determine the priority of facility maintenance and reflect it in the safety and maintenance management plan. 5. 3.3 Dam Maintenance (1) Depletion Planning
① The depletion of the dam shall be carried out in accordance with an appropriate depletion plan after confirming the necessary items to be completed before depletion.
② The depletion plan shall consider the outflow at the dam site, the safety of the dam, flood control measures, the settlement of property rights within the reservoir, river conditions, and downstream water management before depletion.
③ The start of depletion shall be the point at which the transition flow’s gravity drain is closed.
④ Before depletion, the following items shall be appropriately handled and it shall be confirmed that the dam can be depleted safely and with sufficient function.
a. Dam body
b. Various management facilities
c. Relocation of submerged roads
d. Compensation for land and property rights within the submerged area
e. Safety measures for landslides around the reservoir
f. Drainage measures near the upstream river of the reservoir
g. Installation of boundary stakes for the land
(2) Management during Depletion
① During depletion, management shall be carried out to secure the safety of the dam during the period from the start of depletion to the time required after full supply level.
② As the dam first receives external pressure such as water pressure during the depletion process, safety must be secured through an appropriate plan.
③ After the start of depletion and until the full supply level is reached, measurements, inspections, and surveys necessary to monitor the behavior or condition of the dam and the surrounding original ground due to the increase in load caused by the rise in water level shall be carried out.
④ If measurement values such as infiltration, pore water pressure, deformation, and seepage pressure increase rapidly or increase over time under the same load conditions, or if other abnormal behavior occurs, necessary emergency measures shall be taken for the safety of the dam.
⑤ As part of the emergency measures, plans and facilities for lowering the water level shall be secured.
(3) Management of Structures, etc.
① In order to secure the safety of the dam, it shall be managed from after full supply level until the period when the dam’s behavior reaches a normal state and thereafter.
② In order to secure the safety of the dam, the dam structures, the reservoir, and the original ground around the reservoir shall be managed.
③ Management of structures shall be carried out in accordance with separately defined management standards, and necessary measures shall be taken immediately if any abnormalities are found through measurements and inspections.
④ All structures, including the dam, shall be regularly inspected with attention to the following items.
a. Confirmation of structural safety
b. Detection of conditions that hinder operation and manipulation
c. Judgment of normal function
⑤ The general inspection items for regular inspection are as follows, and the inspection schedule shall be established so that the behavior of the structure can be investigated at low water level and at flood level.
a. Abnormal subsidence, uplift, displacement, and lateral movement
b. Concrete cracking or joint separation, collapse
c. Abnormal leakage
d. Erosion of the downstream drainage structure or foundation
e. Other abnormal behavior 5. 3.4 Weir Management (1) Weirs, serving as flood control channels, are composed of weirs for discharge control and gates, and energy dissipation structures. Due to the potential for damage caused by high-speed discharge through the weirs, careful management is essential. (2) Operation of weir gates is based on the optimal flood control method for the reservoir, and the sequential operation of multiple gates typically used in weirs is intended to ensure the hydraulic stability of the floodwater discharged through the weirs. ① Establishing the order of gate operation, methods, and limitations on the gate operation height for each operation is crucial for the stable operation of the dam. ② The gate opening width significantly affects downstream river water levels, so the opening width for each gate should be limited to a certain value to ensure stable discharge from the dam. ③ Limitations should be placed on the gate start interval to facilitate smooth gate operation and prevent mechanical and electrical overload; another gate should be operated after one gate has started. ④ Gates should not be opened or closed unless it is necessary for the following reasons, or for weir inspection and maintenance. a. To secure the required river flow for downstream river use. b. To maintain a constant water level. c. To discharge floodwater from the reservoir during flood events. d. When inspection or maintenance of the dam, reservoir facilities, or structures is required. e. In the event of an emergency necessitating unavoidable action. (3) The names of weir gates should be standardized to prevent errors during gate operation, inspection, and maintenance, thereby avoiding major accidents. (4) When floodwater enters a weir without gates, causing the water level to rise and coinciding with the start of discharge from the spillway, a significant amount of discharge may occur. Therefore, a flood warning zone should be established considering the rate of rise in downstream river water levels. 5. 3.5 Intake Facility Management (1) The dam manager shall take emergency measures and operate the intake gate when an emergency occurs or is likely to occur at the intake facility. (2) A log shall be recorded and kept, containing the following items regarding the management of the intake facility: ① Water level and intake volume ② Operation/closure time and degree of opening of the gate ③ Condition of the intake, structures, machinery, and associated facilities ④ Other matters related to intake operation. 5. 3.6 Discharge Facility Management (1) The gate or valve of the discharge facility shall be operated to the appropriate height or opened to discharge the desired amount of water downstream of the dam, according to the pre-prepared discharge flow curve. (2) Since the water discharge through the discharge channel provides a smaller flow rate downstream of the dam compared to flood conditions, the operation of the discharge gate should be performed considering special factors such as gate movement and tailwater influence during low-flow discharge, unlike flood discharge. 5. 3.7 Instrumentation Management (1) The dam manager shall observe the installed instrumentation facilities for dam safety and analyze data such as displacement, leakage, and pore water pressure to assess the deformation and stability of the dam. (2) The purpose of installing instrumentation equipment on the dam body, foundation, or their contact surface is as follows: ① Construction management of the dam ② Safety management after completion ③ Acquisition of structural analysis data for future design ④ Dam operation and maintenance (3) The instrumentation items shall be designed by understanding the significance of instrumentation, related management items, and the dam type according to the purpose of instrumentation. ① For the instrumentation facilities of a fill dam, refer to KDS 54 30 00. "4.5) shall apply. ② Regarding instrumentation for concrete face rockfill dams with watertight wall, refer to KDS 54 40 00(" "4.7) shall apply. ③ Regarding instrumentation for concrete gravity dams, refer to KDS 54 50 00(" "4.5) shall apply. ④ Instrumentation for roller-compacted concrete dams shall comply with KDS 54 60 00(" "4.7) shall apply.⑤ Regarding the instrumentation facilities of Hardfell Dam, refer to KDS 54 65 00(" 4.8) Complies with 4.8. (4) The dam manager shall continuously inspect and manage the instrumentation to maintain its reliability. (5) If the instrumentation reaches the end of its service life or loses functionality due to other reasons, the dam manager shall analyze the resulting impact and, if necessary, seek ways to supplement it. (6) The dam manager shall preserve the instrumentation’s design, construction data, and measurement data to be utilized for future dam safety management. 5. 3.8 Dam Accident Prevention and Emergency Response (1) Dam Accident Prevention, etc. ① The dam manager shall establish appropriate measures and plans regarding dam accident prevention and maintenance and improvement of the dam necessary for preventing dam failures or accidents and maintaining the functions of the dam and reservoir. ② If there are inherent hazards to facilities or safety around the dam and within the reservoir area, the dam manager shall establish an early warning detection plan using the latest monitoring technology for rapid emergency response through a separate monitoring system. (2) Dam Emergency Response Plan ① The dam manager shall be familiar with emergency procedures during a dam emergency in accordance with the dam emergency response plan established by the dam management entity in accordance with Article 22-2 of the Reservoir and Dam Act and respond to emergency situations. ② The dam management entity shall establish an emergency response plan and review the following items annually, supplementing them if changes are necessary. a. Overview of the dam and surrounding environment b. Emergency communication system c. Procedures for issuing emergency alarms, etc. d. Emergency first aid procedures e. Other matters necessary for emergency response ③ The dam manager may, in the event of a change in safety standards or structure related to dam safety, or a significant change in the downstream river, or upon instruction from the dam management entity, revise the emergency response plan as an agent of the dam management entity. (3) Dealing with Dam Accidents ① The dam manager shall immediately take emergency safety measures if defects or accidents occur that substantially impair the safety and function of the dam. ② When a major defect, collapse, or other accident occurs at the dam, the dam manager shall establish and investigate an investigation team consisting of related ministries, experts, etc. ③ The dam manager shall immediately report the occurrence status, emergency measures, and results of the accident cause investigation to relevant agencies. ④ The dam manager shall assign at least one dam safety management worker who is familiar with the characteristics of the dam itself and the dam site so that they can appropriately assess potential risk conditions. ⑤ If the dam safety management worker discovers any of the following abnormal behaviors or signs that could cause dam failure or accidents, they shall take action according to the emergency response procedures to prevent and mitigate them. a. Overtopping due to flood flow b. Erosion of the dam body due to storms or typhoons c. Slope activity (sliding) on the upstream and downstream slopes of the dam body d. Infiltration and leakage e. Collapse of auxiliary structures. 5. 3.9 Installation and Operation of Dam Flood Warning System (1) The dam manager shall install and operate a dam flood warning system, which comprehensively includes hydrometeorological facilities for observing precipitation, water level, etc. in the upstream and downstream areas of the dam, and alarm broadcasting facilities for notifying downstream residents of precautions through voice broadcasts, sirens, or loudspeakers when releasing water from the dam reservoir. (2) Hydrometeorological facilities shall consist of observation equipment (water level gauges and rain gauges, etc.), observation data storage and transmission devices, communication devices, and power devices. Alarm broadcasting facilities shall consist of speakers, alarm devices, communication devices, and power devices. (3) The dam flood warning system may be selectively duplicated depending on its importance and site conditions. (4) The dam manager shall establish operational management criteria for the dam flood warning system to ensure efficient water resource management and disaster prevention. (5) The dam manager shall conduct regular and ad hoc inspections and maintenance to ensure that the dam flood warning system is always operational. 5.4 Reservoir Water Quality and Environmental Management 5. 4.1 Water Quality and Ecological Environment Management (1) Reservoir Water Environment ① The dam manager shall, in the event of any unusual phenomenon such as rapid changes in water quality within the reservoir or abnormal proliferation of organisms, cooperate with relevant agencies to analyze the cause, identify the impact on water quality and aquatic ecosystems, and take preventive measures in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. ② The dam manager shall, in the event of a significant increase in the number of algae in the reservoir or if an increase is anticipated, cooperate with relevant agencies to analyze the cause and minimize the occurrence and damage. (2) Management of Turbid Water and Floating Debris ① Before the flood season, the dam manager shall investigate the upstream area of the reservoir to identify sources of turbid water and floating debris, and request appropriate measures from relevant agencies, etc., to minimize the inflow of turbid water and floating debris into the reservoir. ② The dam manager may selectively discharge turbid water that has entered the reservoir, taking into account the degree of turbidity in the reservoir operation and the downstream river. ③ If floating debris enters the reservoir, the dam manager shall promptly collect it to maintain the cleanliness of the reservoir area, and shall consult or conclude an agreement with the relevant local autonomous body in advance in accordance with Article 31 of the Water Environment Conservation Act for the transportation and disposal of the collected floating debris. (3) The dam manager shall, through review of relevant reports, on-site surveys, etc., identify in advance the status of pollutant emissions from point/non-point pollution sources within the dam basin and from these pollution sources. (4) The dam manager may install and operate water conservation facilities (submerged aeration facilities, algal control barriers, artificial wetlands, etc.) within the reservoir area to conserve and improve water quality. 5. 4.2 Source Water Management and Emergency Response (1) Pollution Surveillance ① The dam manager shall promptly report the incident to the relevant authorities and take necessary measures when discovering actions that may pollute the water quality of the reservoir. (2) Response to Pollution Accidents ① The manager shall establish response systems for each type of accident in preparation for sudden water pollution accidents, such as oil spills and fish kills, that directly affect the reservoir area and dam reservoir in areas directly impacting them. They shall conduct mock drills to ensure rapid and systematic containment measures can be taken in the event of a water pollution accident. ② The manager shall establish a permanent emergency contact network for prompt response to reservoir water quality conservation and water pollution accidents, and maintain close cooperation with related authorities to ensure smooth communication.
